summary.p: Thanks for the gifts sent to him. He is concerned because there are rumors that Bullinger approves of Ambrosius Blarer's WÃ¼rttemberg Concord on the Lord's Supper and even wants to preach something similar. Karlstadt, of course, does not believe this, but still asks for a brief written explanation so that he can better defend Bullinger against such accusations. Therefore, he also requests the sending of Bullinger's "Assertio utriusque in Christo naturae". Greetings.

div.p: Greetings. I thank you, most prudent Bullinger. For I have received the most delightful gifts you sent. However, there is a rumor that you approve of what Mr. Blarer did due to infirmity, or rather what he did to allow himself to announce Christ to the infirm, in such a way that many fear you will publish something similar in public sermons. I do not believe this at all. For I know your learning and constancy. Therefore, it would be in your interest to send me a note on this matter, so that I may silence the mouths of those who suspect you of introducing the milk of infirmity to those already strong and edified in the Lord. Thus, with such gentleness, I have been pleased to narrate what they somewhat harshly chatter about. If you consider what I say as a wound, know that it comes from charity and that I seek nothing else but to defend the honor of one who has deserved well of me with a certain reason. Therefore, send the Assertion as soon as possible, since I always strive with all my might to preserve your honor and reputation and that of all the people of Zurich.
Farewell happily. Greet the lords and patrons lovingly.
To the most learned man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, Zurich Antistes, most esteemed patron and brother.
